man in the nocturnal nerve
center of the University.

business.

campus police. All calls to

Cut Frosh Sports?
By JAY LENROW
At the last meeting of the rules committee
of the National Collegiate Athletic
Association (NCAA) there was a ruling to
allow freshmen baseball players to play on
varsity squads.
This means that the only 2 sports in which
frosh can't compete on a varisty level are
football and basketball. This move was
made under incrasing pressure from small
colleges which did not have the budgets to
run freshman programs in baseball. The
rules of the Mid-Atlantic Conference (MAC)
are the same as the NCAA rules.
Hopkins does not allow freshmen to play
varisty sports. This is the ruling of the
Department of Athletics. Hopkins is a
university that is presently going through a
financial crisis. Every year there is some
professor who decides that the best way to
cut down on expenses is to cut out the
athletic program. Students must now pay to
bring wives and dates to football, basketball
and lacrosse games.
The Athletic department overlooks what
may be one of the easiest ways to cut costs.
Cut out the freshman sports programs in the
minor sports. The result will be a considerable savings.
There are full freshman schedules in
track and cross-country when there aren't
even enough runners to fill a varisty team.

There are full freshman schedules in track
and cross-country when there aren't even
enough runners to fill a varsity team, there
is a freshman wrestling team when the
varsity has to forfeit weight classes in every
match. The same is true of the golf team the
swimming team, and the fencing team. For
them, having freshmen on varsity squads
would be a boost, and would help keep frosh
interested.
Different Story
With some other teams the story is different. The tennis and baseball teams suffer
from another problem. They have enough
people to field teams, but their facilities are
terribly overtaxed. There are only six tennis
courts available to the team. This means a
maximum of 24 players if everyone plays
doubles. Because they are not eligible for the
varsity, freshmen can only use the courts
when the varsity is not practicing.
There is only one field for the baseball
team to practice on. Because of this, the
freshmen practice only when the varsity
does not and has to constantly settle for a
second-rate athletic program.
I call on Athletic Director Marshall Turner
to open his eyes to the situation as it exists
today. There is no real reason for keeping
freshmen from participating in varsity
athletics. If the NCAA can allow it, Hopkins
should be able to.
